keyTakeAways: A historic heist occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris on Sunday, October 19, 2025, during which four thieves broke into the Apollo Gallery in seven minutes and stole nine high-value artifacts.

Among the stolen items are a sapphire diadem, emerald necklace and earrings from Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and a variety of pieces from Empress Eugénie, including a diamond bow brooch and reliquary brooch.

The sapphire diadem, once part of the Orléans family and acquired by the Louvre in 1985, contains 24 Ceylon sapphires and over 1,000 diamonds and is believed to have once belonged to Marie Antoinette.
The emerald necklace, a wedding gift from Napoleon to Marie-Louise in 1810, was crafted by François-Régnault Nitot and later preserved by her descendants before being acquired by the Louvre in 2004.
The reliquary brooch, made for Empress Eugénie in 1855 by Paul-Alfred Bapst, contains the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, which were given to Louis XIV by Cardinal Mazarin in 1661.

The diamond bow brooch, originally part of a 4,000-stone belt exhibited at the 1855 Universal Exhibition, was transformed into a standalone piece and later purchased in 1887 by Caroline Astor for 42,200 francs.
The Louvre acquired the brooch in 2008 for 6.72 million euros, making it a significant cultural and financial investment.
One of the stolen items, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered near the scene but was damaged during the heist, indicating physical security failures and potential for irreversible loss.
Art recovery expert Arthur Brand described the theft as a 'national disaster' for France, emphasizing that the stolen items are historically and culturally significant national treasures.

The thieves are believed to have dismantled, sold, and melted down the stolen jewels, particularly due to their high gold and silver content and recognizable design, which makes them prime for resale.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major heist occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris on Sunday, October 19, 2025, where four thieves broke into the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes and stole nine historically significant artifacts, including an emerald necklace from Napoleon to Marie-Louise and several items belonging to Empress Eugénie. Among the stolen pieces are a sapphire diadem, a reliquary brooch, and a diamond bow brooch, all crafted by 19th-century Parisian jewelers and containing diamonds of immense historical value, such as the Mazarin diamonds. The theft is described by art expert Arthur Brand as a 'national disaster' due to the cultural and emotional significance of these royal heirlooms. While one item — Eugénie’s crown — was recovered near the scene, it was damaged. Experts believe the thieves dismantled and sold the stolen jewelry, particularly due to their gold and silver content. The Louvre, which acquired many of these items through historical transfers, including from the Orléans family and private collectors, is now confronting a crisis in the security of its crown jewels and national heritage.
title: Historic jewels stolen in ‘national disaster’ for France: What we know about missing Louvre treasures
